channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Stunner: U.S. women's water polo team loses out on a medal after Netherlands defeat
item.description: The U.S. women's water polo team was chasing a historic fourth straight Olympic gold medal. Instead, the team will miss out on the podium for the first time since the sport made its debut in 2000.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. women's water polo team was chasing a historic fourth straight Olympic gold medal. Instead, the team will miss out on the podium for the first time since the sport made its debut in 2000.

(Image credit: Andreas Solaro)
item.dc:creator: Juana Summers

item.title: In a first since the war began, Ukraine launched an invasion into Russia
item.description: Ukraine invaded Russia this week - an attack that was shocking in scope and execution. Ukraine’s cross-border incursion into western Russia is now in its fifth day.
item.content:encoded: Ukraine invaded Russia this week - an attack that was shocking in scope and execution. Ukraine’s cross-border incursion into western Russia is now in its fifth day.
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Opinion: RFK Jr.'s Central Park 'Bear-B-Q' stunt
item.description: In an election season rife with surprises, you might add this week’s revelation by Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
item.content:encoded:
In an election season rife with surprises, you might add this week’s revelation by Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

(Image credit: Jessica Kourkounis)
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Olympic athletes in Paris are winning medals. They're also voicing wisdom
item.description: Athletes at press conferences are famous for talking in cliches. But in Paris, a lot of Olympians are going deep, voicing wisdom and sharing their truths.
item.content:encoded: Athletes at press conferences are famous for talking in cliches. But in Paris, a lot of Olympians are going deep, voicing wisdom and sharing their truths.
item.dc:creator: Brian Mann

item.title: Week in politics: The Harris-Walz campaign takes off
item.description: We look at how Vice President Kamala Harris's presidential campaign is taking shape, with the massive influx of donations and the selection of Minnesota's Gov. Tim Walz at her running mate.
item.content:encoded: We look at how Vice President Kamala Harris's presidential campaign is taking shape, with the massive influx of donations and the selection of Minnesota's Gov. Tim Walz at her running mate.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: What the Secret Service has changed a month after the assassination attempt on Trump
item.description: It's been one month since the attempt on former President Trump's life. NPR's Scott Simon talks with Washington Post reporter Carol Leonnig about pressures on the Secret Service.
item.content:encoded: It's been one month since the attempt on former President Trump's life. NPR's Scott Simon talks with Washington Post reporter Carol Leonnig about pressures on the Secret Service.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: UK's worst riots in years were incited by online disinformation about asylum seekers
item.description: NPR’s Scott Simon speaks to Dr. Marc Owen-Jones, a disinformation researcher, about the role of social media during race riots in the UK.
item.content:encoded: NPR’s Scott Simon speaks to Dr. Marc Owen-Jones, a disinformation researcher, about the role of social media during race riots in the UK.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: A convention center in Chicago was a death trap for birds. New decals may change that
item.description: Chicago's McCormick Place is in the middle of a major migratory bird path, and its' lakeside building will soon have bird safe decals that could prevent thousands of bird collisions and death.
item.content:encoded: Chicago's McCormick Place is in the middle of a major migratory bird path, and its' lakeside building will soon have bird safe decals that could prevent thousands of bird collisions and death.
item.dc:creator: Juanpablo Ramirez-Franco

item.title: Ten years after Michael Brown's death, police killings are not going down
item.description: Ten years ago, a white police officer killed Michael Brown, a Black teen in Ferguson, Mo. His death prompted nationwide protests and a White House report on American policing. How much has changed since his death?
item.content:encoded: Ten years ago, a white police officer killed Michael Brown, a Black teen in Ferguson, Mo. His death prompted nationwide protests and a White House report on American policing. How much has changed since his death?
item.dc:creator: Meg Anderson

item.title: Black hospitals vanished in the U.S. decades ago. Some communities have paid a price
item.description: Hundreds of Black hospitals in the U.S. closed after passage of the Civil Rights Act when health care became integrated. Black communities lost a source of employment and pride.
item.content:encoded:
Hundreds of Black hospitals in the U.S. closed after passage of the Civil Rights Act when health care became integrated. Black communities lost a source of employment and pride.

(Image credit: Missouri Valley Special Collections)
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sausser
